title: Will we take on the debt of my father in law who passed away?
question: He passed away in Ukraine, and we are unaware of his money situation. We heard that he was in debt and may have owed taxes here in the states. Any of his debt was likely tax, and or credit card. Most likely no medical debt.
answers:
Father-in-Law's US debts, even tax debts, usually can't be enforced against his children or heirs personally unless they were co- borrowers or taxpayers with him in a business or something. Hoever, those US debts, especially tax debt, can often be enforced against property he owned here, even if it is now in the possession of his heirs. In other words, you most likely don't owe his debt, but you may have property of his that his creditors are entitled to.

If you're talking about foreign (non-US) debt being enforced here, this seems like a remote possibility unless the amount is very large. You should speak with an experienced attorney in your area and let him or her ask lots of questions. Then they can let you know whether or here is any risk to you. Good luck.

I am sorry to hear about your father-in-law's passing. You mentioned that he MAY have debts here in the United States. Any creditor whom your father-in-law owed money to can now come after his estate and ask to be paid through his estate. This is of course assuming he owned anything of value at the time of his death. Your father-in-law's "estate" is everything that he owns when he died, which may include real property, bank accounts, personal properties, investment accounts, retirement accounts, interest in businesses, etc.

If your father-in-law doesn't is passing his properties to his heirs, the creditors can try and recover the debt from your father-in-law's heirs. Whomever is the administrator or personal representative of the estate will have to communicate with the creditors and figure out if anything should be paid to the creditors.

But if you're asking whether you and your spouse, or your other family members would have to pay the creditors back with your OWN money, the answer is "No" so long as you guys did not receive any sort of inheritance/transfer from your father-in-law at the time of his death and you guys didn't co-sign on for the debt.

I hate to quote cliché, but "the sins of the father cannot be imposed upon the son, even if proved." If he died as a resident of Ukraine, then CALIFORNIA Law doesn't really help you solve this problem. Look to the laws of the state where he resided at the time of his death
